<http://spectrum.ieee.org/energywise/green-tech/conservation/paper-origami-energy-harvesters>

attachments.text: Slinky-like devices generate small amounts of power from the same effect behind static electricity
attachments.fallback: Slinky-like devices generate small amounts of power from the same effect behind static electricity

text: reminds me of this energy harvesting IC: <http://www.linear.com/product/LTC3588-1>

attachments.text: The LTC&reg;3588-1 integrates a low-loss full-wave bridge rectifier with a high efficiency buck converter to form a complete energy harvesting solution optimized for high output impedance energy sources such as piezoelectric, solar, or magnetic transducers
attachments.fallback: The LTC&reg;3588-1 integrates a low-loss full-wave bridge rectifier with a high efficiency buck converter to form a complete energy harvesting solution optimized for high output impedance energy sources such as piezoelectric, solar, or magnetic transducers

text: little piezo beam gets deflected and generates tiny amount of power
from vibration
Say, wouldn't it be smart to use that kind of harvesting on bridges
Use the motion of existing infrastructure to reclaim some energy
Or at train stops
sure, definitely possible to harvest energy those kind of places. I think it only makes sense where it's cost prohibitive to run power.
My senior project in engineering was an energy reclamation device! Some team members went on to start a company with the tech: <http://solepowertech.com/>
<@U026PT0D7>: cool!
<@U026PHQ3J> actually, Formula One is doing a lot of research into regenerative braking. Specifically kinetic-based (braking the car spins up a flywheel).
and I believe electric trains already use it (though some non-trivial amount must be wasted as heat, I assume)
They do. My stepdad is obsessed with it
They call them motes
<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regenerative_brake#Conversion_to_electric_energy:_the_motor_as_a_generator>
I'm enamored with flywheels myself. I dream of a woodshop with flywheel-powered floor tools. Obviously the flywheel would be charged with a foot-treadle, or stationary bike.
